p.s: Throughout the novel, Delaney often shifts from his humanist tendencies to his paranoia slowly building up a hatred against illegal mexicanMexican immigrants.
In this chapter, upon seeing a mexicanMexican, he immediately suspects them of wanting to do something bad.
In the following I am going to analyse Delaney's state of mind throughout this excerpt.
The novel is mostly written from the view of a third-person-narratorthird-person narrator.

At the beginning, Delaney is reminescingreminscing about his losses and realises that he has to accept that sad reality of his own (l. 7) ... the worlds spread out before him, glum, dogless, on his own. With dogless he is referingreferring to both of his dogs that got eaten by coyotes and with on his own he is referring to the people who are in favour of building a gate around Arroyo Blanco to which he is opposed to and Los Angeles, California as a whole which is known to be full of illegal mexicanMexican immigrants he cannot trust.
At this moment his mind is filled with sadness and distrust.
His mindset soon switches though because when he sees a blank figure in the background approchingapproaching the Cherrystones' property, he comes closer, but does not immediately act.

quote.s: ... Delaney came closer still, and noticed something else, something that struck him with the force of a blow: Thethe man was Mexican.

p.s: In this passage you can see that Delaney only started acting upon finding out that the man is mexicanMexican, and that is a form of micro-aggression.
WIth that his state of mind shifted from his sadness to immediate anger, as he does treat the man harshly.

(ll. 25-26)... didn't Kyra say that the man who'd threatened her at the Da Ros place was wearing a Podres cap turned backwards? Upon that realisation he does not even fact check if that really is the man whom has threatened his wife and his anger just gradually increases.
As you can see, Delaney's questions towards José get after each question even more aggressive until he straight up commands José to say what he is doing there in line 37.
I want to know what you think you're doing here.
Delaney's anger and aggressivenes get to the point where he tries to use brute force to get José to speak by grabbing his forearm (ll. 42-43) ... he had hold of the man's forearm.
As a reader of this novel we know that José is, in fact not trying to rob the Cherrystones, and instead is handing out fliersflyers, which he does say to Delaney (ll. 46-47) I got these flies.

In the heat of the moment Delaney did not pay any attention to that and thus could not make out what the man meant with flies, as he was aggrevating the situation by focusing on the fact that José spat between his feet.
His aanger, that has worsened, can be seen in line 48.
Delaney was riding the crest of the moment, trembling, angry, ready for anything.

At this point, you can tell that he insanely mad and full of hatred, as he calls the man bad things such as a thief, and a liar, but also makes some racist remarks such as the stinking occupant of a stinking sleeping bag in the state forest, a trespasser, a polluter, a Mexican (ll. 49-50).
With all the things he said and listed with an enumeration, he basically just puts his definition of a mexicanMexican.
And he is not only referring to the illegal mexicanMexican immigrants, he said Mexican, just discriminated every existing mexicanMexican.
Then when José finally takes out the flierflyer and repeats himself, Delaney realises he was in the wrong, his anger turned into shame, so devastated he couldn't speak (l. 60).
He was wrong about something that he thought was right and is now fully ashamed, yet does not apologise to José anyway.

Throughout this whole chapter, Delaney's state of mind goes from sadness, to pure anger when he sees a mexicanMexican and finally shame when he finds out that the mexicanMexican was right and he was not.
